vectorData.altText: That's right! The splenic artery is one of the three branches of the celiac trunk. It spirals to the left and passes through the splenorenal ligament to reach the the hilus of the spleen.

i) the short gastric arteries, which ascend along the greater curvature of the stomach, within the greater omentum, to its fundus, and 
ii) the left gastro-omental (gastro-epiploic) artery, which descends along the greater curvature of the stomach, in the greater omentum. The latter artery anastomoses with the right gastro-omental (gastro-epiploic) artery within the greater omentum.

The Splenic Artery
The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk. It runs to the left, retroperitoneally, toward the spleen. It passes through the splenorenal ligament to access the hilum of the spleen. Before entering the hilum of the spleen, it gives rise to the following branches that pass through the gastrosplenic ligament to access the greater curvature of the stomach.
